item.title: Double yellow lines on junction of Beechwood Rise and Edgebury, 28th October
item.description:
Following the recent road resurfacing of Edgebury, at the junction of Edgebury and Beechwood Rise, the double yellow lines on Edgebury have been repainted. However, unfortunately that was not continued for a few metres onto those on Beechwood Rise. To be fair it probably wasn't it their remit, but if common sense had prevailed they would have done so. Please can you give the remaing half of the double yellow lines a lick of paint! Thank you

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Beechwood Rise, Chislehurst, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: See ref 8344996 - As with the bus stop directly opposite, the bus stop markings have not been painted back on for this stop after the road resurfacing. (Probably also missing some double yellow lines at the junction with Belmont) do, 28th October
item.description:
See above, missing bus stop markings after resurfacing. This needs doing URGENTLY, if not once Edgebury school returns next week, parents will park very close to this bus stop on either side, which impacts the 160 bus route travelling in the direction of Catford, pulling in to pick up/ drop off passengers.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): 84, Edgebury, Elmstead, London
Report on FixMyStreet

item.title: Behind the 39 Prince Henry Road, SE78PP house, 28th October
item.description:
Dear Sir/Madam, I am writing to raise an ongoing issue concerning the condition of the area surrounding a tree behind my property at 39 Prince Henry Road, SE78PP. A few years ago, the tree commission arranged for this tree to be cut down due to its poor and unsafe condition. However, the removal was only partially completed at that time, and the site was left in disrepair. More recently (around one to two months ago) the remaining part of the tree was finally cut down, but all of the cuttings and waste material have still not been cleared away. As a result: 1. Tree debris remains on site: large branches, stumps, and other remnants of the tree are still lying on the ground and now rotting. 2. Litter accumulation: over time, rubbish has gathered around the debris, creating an unsightly and unhygienic mess. 3, Safety and environmental concerns: the site is attracting pests, posing a potential hazard to residents, and detracting from the local environment. I have attached recent photographs showing the current state of the area. I kindly request that the Greenwich Council: Arrange for the prompt clearance and removal of all remaining tree debris and accumulated litter. Conduct a site inspection to ensure the area is left in a safe and properly maintained condition going forward. Please confirm receipt of this message and advise when the cleanup is expected to take place. I trust the Council will take swift action to address this ongoing issue before it worsens further. Thank you for your attention and assistance. Kind regards, Tatsiana.

Nearest road to the pin placed on the map (automatically generated by OpenStreetMap): Greenbay Road, Charlton, London
Report on FixMyStreet
